subject: Business
title: When to Kill a Strategy
description: A quick, practical guide to When to Kill a Strategy.

hook.text: Nokia's smartphone strategy was failing in 2010. Everyone inside knew it. Nobody said it aloud for two years.

buildup.text: Strategies have expiration dates. Market conditions change. Competitors adapt. Assumptions become invalid.

discovery.text: The hardest part isn't building a strategy â€” it's admitting the current one has failed.

twist.text: Sunk cost bias, political careers, and ego keep dead strategies alive far past their expiration.

climax.text: Intel killed its memory chip business in 1985 â€” its founding product â€” and pivoted to processors.

punchline.text: A good strategist knows when to stop. That takes more courage than starting.

quiz.question: Why do organizations often fail to kill a failing strategy?
options: Sunk cost bias, ego, and internal politics keep it alive
Strategies always improve if given more time
Changing strategy is illegal under corporate law
